properties.entry: The device group (and all it's child groups) that this monitor will use to look for violating devices
The device group that this monitor places any devices it finds that are in violation of the processors. "N/A" means the system cannot acquire the data.
The number of devices that are in violation of the processors (also the number of devices in the violation device group)
The number of devices within the monitoring device group (and all it's child groups)

The number of devices within the monitoring device group (and all it's child groups) that support having all of the assigned processors. Because of this there can be more missing points than supported
Whether or not this monitor is enabled or disabled. Note: when a monitor is disabled any violating devices are cleared out

Finding Violating Devices
The configured status and value based processors define the rules that cause a device to be placed in the monitor's violation group. A device will be placed in the violations group if any of the attributes being monitored break the rule defined by the processor. If multiple rules are broken, the device will stay in the violations group until all selected attributes are in valid states in relation to the defined rules.

Adding and removing from the Violations Group
For a value based rule, please select the attribute to monitor and the rule to evaluate when a new value is received. Evaluations include is the attribute value greater than the defined threshold, less than the defined threshold, does the value land within a defined minimum and maximum range of thresholds, or does the value land outside of a defined minimum and maximum range of thresholds. Multiple value based rules may be defined per data monitor and if the attribute's data value breaks any of the defined rules, the device will be placed in the violations group
Min must be less than Max.

Points contained in this list either do not have the point created for a given device or the point is created, however it has a different state group than what is assigned in your monitor's processor. For example, say the following is displayed in your list:

Current Loss (TrueFalse - default: Event Status) : 247

This means that 247 of your total supported monitoring devices either:

1: Are missing the "Current Loss" point (with a State Group of "TrueFalse").

or

2: Have the "Current Loss" point, but have a State Group other than "TrueFalse" assigned.

The "default: Event Status" is simply to let you know that the default State Group for the "Current Loss" point is "Event Status" (meaning there is a good chance "Event Status" is the State Group that your monitoring devices would have and not "TrueFalse").

Clicking on "Add Points" will bring you to a different page that will let you add supported points to your monitoring devices. This page does not have the ability to change the State Group of existing points, however. So, in the example above, this page would not be helpful if your 247 devices already had the "Current Loss" point, but had a different State Group than "TrueFalse". To remedy that situation you would need to change them individually using Database Editor.

The configured status and value based processors define the rules that cause a device to be placed in the monitor's violation group. A device will be placed in the violations group if any of the attributes being monitored break the rule defined by the processor. If multiple rules are broken, the device will stay in the violations group until all selected attributes are in valid states in relation to the defined rules.
Adding and removing from the Violations Group

For a status based rule, please select the attribute to monitor and the state that defines a violation of the rule. Multiple status based rules may be defined per data monitor and if the attribute matches any of the defined states, the device will be considered in violation of the rules and placed in the violations group.
Update functionality is disabled while calculating.

Missing: Too Many Devices to Report

Unfortunately we cannot list an accurate number here, but you can still inspect the list of devices using the magnifying glass, and you can use the other controls normally.
